Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Destruction of Cyanotoxins using Ferrates

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
1236331/1235636/1235803/1236209
Sharma/Westrick/O'Shea/Dionysiou

There is serious concern over the human health impacts of cyanobacteria, commonly referred to as blue green algae, in drinking water reservoirs worldwide. Cyanobacterial harmful algal blooms (Cyano-HABs) have been especially problematic in the Great Lakes and Florida Watersheds in recent years. The Great Lakes contain one-fifth of the world?s freshwater and provide drinking water to over 24 million Canadian and U.S. citizens. In this region, there are reports of cyano-HABs events at least at six locations in Lake Ontario, seven locations in Lake Erie, three locations in Lake Huron, and two locations in Lake Michigan. Cyanobacteria produce taste and odour compounds but pose a serious environmental hazard because of the release of potent water soluble toxic compounds, called cyanotoxins (i.e., hepatotoxins, dermatotoxins, neurotoxins). Microcystins (MCs), which are hepatotoxic cyclic peptide toxins, are the most widespread cyanotoxins. As global climate change occurs, cyano-HABs are predicted to increase in both frequency and toxicity.

The increase in HABs and the negative health effects of MCs have resulted in an urgent need to identify efficient water treatment methods to eliminate cyanotoxins from water supplies. Physical methods can be employed to remove MCs however such methods do not destroy the toxins and the associated treatment costs are generally prohibitive. Oxidative transformation of cyanotoxins to less toxic by-products offers an attractive option for treatment of contaminated water. Conventional oxidative technologies, such as chlorination, UV, and ozonization are often not cost effective. In addition, the formation of toxic by-products, including bromate and disinfection by products are major drawbacks. High-valent iron-based tetra-oxy compounds, ferrates (FeVIO42-, Fe(VI), FeVO43-, Fe(V) and FeIVO43-, (Fe(IV)) are emerging disinfectants and promising oxidizing agents for water treatment and can address the concerns associated with the current treatment technologies. Fe(V) and Fe(IV) are more powerful oxidant than Fe(VI) and may efficiently treat chlorine resistant microorganisms and toxins. This research will investigate the degradation of toxins by different ferrates under natural water conditions without producing toxic byproducts. Additionally, a novel photocatalyst will be developed which in presence of Fe(VI) under solar light and visible light irradiation will yield efficient degradation of cyanotoxins.

The research is expected to provide the fundamental mechanistic understanding necessary for the development of rational strategies for optimizing the ferrate process and ferrate-based solar driven photocatalytic process for water treatment. The collaborative project will make a significant contribution in the field of water purification using ferrate technologies. The development of cost-efficient technologies for water purification, especially for small scale treatment plants as response technologies to the seasonal problems of algal blooms will have a significant implication in protecting human health. Additionally, a molecular understanding of the chemistry of ferrate species will help to elucidate the involvement of high-valent iron species in a number of critical biological processes, including aging and diseases. The research activities will promote and foster teaching, mentoring, training and learning through interactions of a compentent research team composed of undergraduate students, graduate students, postdocs and the PIs. The PIs will recruit females and minority students. Outreach activities will provide opportunities to undergraduate and high school students, including from underrepresented groups, for training and research in environmental engineering and science, which will include water monitoring and cyanobacterial identification.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Contamination of water with cyanotoxins has resulted in serious public health and environmental safety concerns due to frequent occurrence of blue-green algae (cyanobacteria) blooms in water.  In the past decade, toxins has been detected in waters of Asian and European countries as well as in drinking water sources of several cities in North America.  In the North America, the Great Lakes contain one-fifth of the world’s freshwater and provide drinking water to more than 24 million Canadian and U.S. citizens.  There are also reports on cyano-HABs (Harmful Algal Blooms) events at six locations in Lake Ontario, seven locations in Lake Erie, three locations in Lake Huron, and two locations in Lake Michigan.  Cyanobacteria create an environmental hazard due to release of water soluble toxic compounds, called cyanotoxins (i.e., hepatotoxins, dermatotoxins, neurotoxins). Among toxins, microcystins (MCs) are the most widespread cyanotoxins. With the change in global climate and increased euthrophication of natural water bodies, the presence of cyano-HABs may increase in frequency and toxicity.  Our project provided environmental friendly methods to decrease and potentially eliminate the toxicity of cyanotoxins (microcystin-LR and cylindrospermopsin)  by treating the contaminated water with high-valent iron compounds,  ferrates (FeVIO42-, FeVI, FeVO43-, FeV and FeIVO43-,  FeIV).  These iron-based species are also emerging disinfectants and promising oxidizing agents for water treatment that also address many concerns of current treatment technologies. For example, conventional treatment by chlorine generates chlorinated disinfection byproducts (DBPs), which are potential carcinogenic compounds.  Another etablished treatment method, ozonation, also produces carcinogenic bromate ion when bromine is in the source water.  Compartively, the ferrates circumvent these concerns in treatment processes.  Furthermore, a series of novel iron-based photocatalysts, ferrites, which were able to utilize solar and visible light irradiation were developed to treat MCs and other contaminants of concern in contaminated water.

The research activties of the supported project have advanced the fundamental undestanding and mechanistic knowledge, imperative for the development of rational strategies for optimizing ferrate processes and ferrate based solar driven photocatalytic process for water treatment.  In the project, we clearly demonstrated effective removal of microcystin-LR and cylindrospermopsin by ferrate species.  Among different ferrate species, FeV and FeIV, were much more reactive than FeVI.  Also, the different high-valent iron species  showed similarities and differences in reactions with microcystin-LR, the first reported examples of such research findings.  Importantly, our results demonstrate the ferrate treatment of cyanotoxin contaminated water can eliminate the associated toxicity.  Overall, our collaborative project contributed to the field of water purification using ferrate technologies, which may also be applicable to small scale treatment plants as response technologies to the seasonal problems of algal blooms. The water treatment processes demonstarted within this project can help protect human health. 

During the period of the collaborative research, researchers have put significant effort on education of drinking water quality, drinking water treatment, mechanism of oxidation, and  water sustainability and pubic health through courses, seminars, lectures, and presentations. Problems caused by emerging contaminants including cyanotoxins and state-of-the-art water treatment processes were extensively discussed in these teaching courses. In teaching courses, advances made in preparing ferrates and ferrites and their effective application for detoxification of toxins and pollutants were presented.  One of the researchers also played an active part in the Summer Institute for underrepresented high school students hosted by the College of Engineering and Applied Sciences at the University of Cincinnatti, Ohio.  In this event, general principles of water treatment and status of algae blooms were introduced. All the collaborative researchers were active in delivering invited talks and keynote lectures at conferences both in the US and abroad. Researchers covered almost every region in the world to dessiminate their results produced from this project.  Additionally, investigators enhance their professional activities under the project by serving chair or co-chair in conference sessions and presented their work in a series of symposia including the national meetings of American Chemical Society, International Sympoium of Environmental Science and Technology, International Chemical Congress of Pacific Basin Societies, Mediterranean Conference on the Applications of the Mössbauer Effect, European Meeting on Solar Chemistry and Photocatalysis, Environmental Applications, International Conference on Advanced Oxidation Technologies for Treatment of Water, Air and Soil and so on.  Our research activities also promoted teaching, training and learning by bringing together a research team composed of undergraduate students, graduate students, visiting faculty and the PIs.  The collaborative research project effectively attracted and trained female and minority graduate and undergraduate student participants.  Participants in the project received training in the critical research areas of environmental engineering and science, including strategies for effective water treatment.   Outreach activities were also successfully conducted bring greater awareness to health impacts of contaminated water and the desperate global need for sustainable water treatment technologies.
